A: 1. Jesus taught us to pray _ (a) without ceasing (b) only sometimes (c) only in church
2. We should pray to God in _ (a) public places (b) secret (c) large gatherings
3. If the answer to our prayer has not come, we should pray without getting _ (a) tired (b) discouraged (c) bored
4. When we pray, we should have belief that God will hear us, which means praying in faith without _ (a) speaking (b) doubt (c) kneeling
5. Jesus taught us to pray for something _ (a) general (b) specific (c) easy to get
6. The homework mentioned in the text is to write the _ prayer (a) Apostles' (b) Lord's (c) Shepherd's
7. Jesus is referred to as the _ of God (a) servant (b) son (c) prophet
8. Jesus has power over all things on _ (a) heaven (b) earth (c) water
9. Jesus demonstrated his power over natural forces by calming the _ (a) river (b) lake (c) sea
10. During the storm, Jesus spoke to the wind and said 'Peace be _' (a) quiet (b) still (c) calm
11. Another way Jesus demonstrated his power over natural forces was by walking on the _ (a) land (b) sea (c) air
12. Approximately how many people followed Jesus to the mountain before the feeding miracle? (a) two thousand (b) three thousand (c) five thousand
13. Jesus asked one of his _ how they could get bread to feed the crowd (a) disciples (b) followers (c) friends
14. The food available before the miracle was five loaves of bread and two small _ (a) birds (b) fishes (c) chickens
15. After eating, all the people were _ (a) hungry (b) satisfied (c) tired
16. After the feeding, how many full baskets of leftovers were collected? (a) 7 (b) 10 (c) 12
17. One person Jesus healed, mentioned in the text, was Peter's _ (a) father (b) mother-in-law (c) brother
18. Jesus also healed a _ man as stated in the text (a) blind (b) deaf (c) paralysed
19. One of the people Jesus raised from the dead was Jairus's _ (a) son (b) daughter (c) wife
20. The Memory Verse in the text is found in Luke _ (a) 7:16 (b) 8:16 (c) 9:16
B: 1. What is the primary teaching about the frequency of prayer Jesus emphasized? _________
2. What specific command did Jesus give to the storm when calming the sea? _________
3. Before the miracle of feeding the five thousand, what was the total amount of food a boy had? _________
4. Name one individual mentioned in the text whom Jesus healed from a disease. _________
5. What is the homework task mentioned in the text? _________
C: 1. Elaborate on Jesus' teachings regarding the manner and purpose of prayer, as outlined in the text.
2. Describe Jesus' power over natural forces, providing specific examples from the text.
3. Recount the event of Jesus feeding the five thousand people, detailing the circumstances, the miracle itself, and its outcome.
4. List and briefly state the significance of the individuals Jesus raised from the dead, according to the provided text.
5. Analyze the meaning and context of the Memory Verse (Luke 7:16) in relation to Jesus' miraculous works.
answers_B: Five loaves of bread and two small fishes.
answers_C: Jesus taught five key ways to pray: pray without ceasing (continually), pray in secret (for intimacy with God, not public display), pray without getting discouraged (persevere in prayer), pray in faith without doubt (believe God will answer), and pray for something specific (know what you are asking for).

Jesus demonstrated divine power over natural forces. One instance was calming a great storm at sea by simply commanding "Peace be still," causing the wind to stop immediately. Another demonstration was His ability to walk on the sea.

After a crowd of five thousand followed Jesus to a mountain, He inquired how to feed them. A boy offered five loaves of bread and two small fishes. Jesus prayed, blessed the food, and distributed it through His disciples. All ate and were satisfied, resulting in 12 full baskets of leftovers.

The text mentions three individuals Jesus raised from the dead: Jairus's Daughter, The widow's son, and Lazarus. These acts underscore Jesus' power over death, confirming His divine authority and role as the Son of God.

The Memory Verse, "A great prophet is risen up among us; and that God has visited his people," reflects the people's understanding and awe of Jesus after witnessing His miracles. It signifies their recognition of Him as a powerful prophet, whose actions demonstrate God's direct presence and intervention among humanity.
